advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>John V. Blankenbaker designed the Kenbak-1 and marketed in the pages of Scientific American in 1971. The machine's name was taken from the middle of John's last name.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.vintage-computer.com" target="_blank">www.vintage-computer.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MENTA & SOFTY ADVERT (FRANCE, SEPT. 82)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The major argument of the advert campaign was "we have a better and cheaper computer than Apple and IBM"...<br><br> True, but like many other computers of the time, the major fault of the Advantage was not to be an IBM system...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-170 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future.... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.K. AD (OCT. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The letters you send speak volumes for your company's image. Scrappy typing, untidy layouts and poor spelling announce that you're less than professional outfit.<br> Whereas beautifully presented correspondence shows quite clearly that you're a company to be reckoned with.<br> Now Amstrad's new wordprocessor with daisywhell printer and spellcheck facility means that any company can produce superb quality letters, reports and documents.<br> With the minimum of effort and for a minimal outlay.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>

computer.description:
This is an extremly rare TRS-80 Model 1 clone, based on an other clone: The Komtek 1 (from Germany).
It's equiped with a Level II basic and powered by a Zilog Z80 cpu.
_________
Contributors : Incog

emulator.description: This program emulates a complete TRS-80
emulator.name: David Keil's TRS-80 Model III/4/4P Emulator Page

emulator.description: This page offers shareware versions of a TRS-80 Model 4 emulator and a TRS-80 Model 1-2 emulator
emulator.name: Matthew Reed's TRS-80 Emulator Web Site

emulator.description: This TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator is a commercial product
emulator.name: TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator

emulator.description: xtrs is a Radio Shack TRS-80 Model I/III/4/4P emulator for Unix and the X Window System
emulator.name: xtrs: TRS-80 Model I/III/4 Emulator for Unix

emulator.description: With this Java emulator, you'll be able to write a BASIC program directly in your browser!
emulator.name: TRS-80 Level I BASIC in a browser

emulator.description: A complete list of TRS-80 emulators for various platforms !
emulator.name: Ira Goldklang's TRS-80 Revived Pages

emulator.description: MESS emulator also emulates a TRS-80 systems
emulator.name: MESS

item.description: Remote Unit Active|||Serial# 26-1210|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> REMOTE UNIT ACTIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1210</strong><br><blockquote>This rare unit is meant for teachers to control up to 16 TRS-80 Model 1 from a another TRS-80 equiped with min-disk. All the controled TRS-80 model 1 must be equiped with Level II. <br><br> It cost 2895fr (France, 1981)</blockquote>

Network II box|||p/n 26-1211|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> NETWORK II BOX</strong></font><br><strong>> p/n 26-1211</strong><br><blockquote>This box allowed up to 16 TRS computer to be networked. Three network boxes were released by Tandy (I, II and III).<br> The Network II required verbal communication between the server operator and the remote user, and data transfer had to be completed one user at a time.<br> The network III allowed automated control of the network so that users could easily access programs and data stored on the server's storage device.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>David Sutherland</b> for the pictures.</p></blockquote>

Daisy Wheel Printer II|||Serial# 26-1158|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAISY WHEEL PRINTER II</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1158</strong><br><blockquote>This is a high-quality printer meant to be used with wordprocessors. Some interchangeable daisy-wheels were available (Courrier, Elite, Madeleine). It could print 163 characters per line (34cm), at a 43 cps rate. <br><br> It cost 9595fr (France, 1981)</blockquote>

Line Printer I |||Ref# 26-7017|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER I </strong></font><br><strong>> Ref# 26-7017</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a custom version of the Oki Microline 80.<br> Printed lower and upper case on paper rolls or listing paper (24cm wide) from 40 to 80 columns/line, at a speed rate of 28 lines/minute. <br><br> It cost 716 Euros in 1981 (France).</blockquote>

Line Printer III|||Serial# 26-1156|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER III</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1156</strong><br><blockquote>This printer can print lower and upper case, at a speed rate of 120 c/s, on paper up to 38cm wide. It is conceived for intensive use ! <br<<br> It cost 9950fr in 1981 (France). </blockquote>

Line Printer VI|||Serial# 26-1166|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER VI</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1166</strong><br><blockquote>This large printer can print lower and upper case, graphic characters and symbols at a speed rate of 100 c/s ! This is definately a professional printer. <br><br> It cost 5495fr in 1981 (France).</blockquote>

Exatron |||Stringy Floppy drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> EXATRON </strong></font><br><strong>> Stringy Floppy drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Exatron Stringy Floppy (ESF) was a low-cost data—storage system that fitted the gap, between cassettes and disk drives.<br> The system was based on a miniature endless—loop tape cartridge called a "wafer".<br> The amount of data that could be recorded on a wafer depended on the length of tape in it, typically, a 50—foot wafer could hold at least 40 KB of programs or data. <br><br> <b>Matt</b> reports to us:<br><font color="#666666"> A curiousity about the model 1, CPU SPEED had a direct relatonship with STORAGE CAPACITY. if you doubled the clock speed of your MODEL 1 CPU you doubled the amount of data you could store on your stringy floppies. this is a feat that no other computer no matter how many ghz you have in your PC can do today without using compression.</font> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>David Sutherland</b> for the pictures</p></blockquote>

computer.name: Model R1001
computer.ports: disk driver port, I/O port, tape interface, printer port, composite video output (monitor), RF TV video output
